Red_Meat_(band):
'''Red Meat''' is a country band that has released the albums ''Meet Red Meat'' (1997), ''Thirteen'' (1999), ''Alameda County Line'' (2001) and ''We Never Close'' (2007). Red Meat formed in 1993 from the remains of the country/surf/polka band The Movie Stars, and the Genuine Diamelles, whose sound was described by their members as a "psychedelic glee club". The last three albums were produced by Dave Alvin, and engineered by Mark Linett. An additional live album, ''Live at the World's Smallest Honky Tonk'', was released in October 2010.

The song "Broken Up and Blue" from ''Thirteen'' is featured on the soundtrack of the 2001 movie ''[[Monster's Ball]]''.<ref>[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0285742/soundtrack Monster's Ball (2001) â€“ Soundtracks<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> The pit orchestra at the [[Academy Awards]] played the song when [[Halle Berry]] accepted her award for best actress.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://springfield.news-leader.com/columnists/brothers/0129-SpiritofMi-281480.html |title=News-Leader.com {{!}} Columnists {{!}} Michael Brothers {{!}} Spirit of Midwest hasn't left West Coast rockers<!-- Bot generated title --> |access-date=2008-04-20 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080205155718/http://springfield.news-leader.com/columnists/brothers/0129-SpiritofMi-281480.html |archive-date=2008-02-05 |url-status=dead }}</ref>

Red Meat has won "Wammies" for best country band, along with a "Best of the Bay" award from the ''San Francisco Bay Guardian'' and "Best of the East Bay" award from the ''East Bay Express''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.eastbayexpress.com/eastbay/readers-poll-winners-arts-and-culture/BestOf?oid=1167898|title = Readers' Poll Winners: Arts & Culture|date = 25 June 2008}}</ref>
